document: Chapter 3: Data Acquisition - Guide to Computer Forensics and Investigations, Fifth Edition

questions.question: Data in a forensics acquisition tool is stored as an image file.
Raw format is the only format for storing digital evidence.
Raw format advantages include fast data transfers and ignoring minor data read errors.
Proprietary formats can be easily shared between different forensic tools.
The Expert Witness format is an official standard for forensic image files.
Advanced Forensics Format (AFF) was developed as a closed-source acquisition format.
AFF design goals include providing compressed or uncompressed image files.
Static acquisitions and live acquisitions are the two types of data acquisitions.
Creating a disk-to-image file is the least common acquisition method.
Disk-to-disk copies are bit-for-bit replications of the original drive.
Logical acquisition captures only specific files of interest to the case.
Sparse acquisition collects fragments of allocated data only.
When making a copy, digital signatures are unnecessary for verification.
You should create only one image of digital evidence.
The host protected area of a disk drive should be copied during acquisition.
Whole disk encryption makes static acquisitions easier.
Acquisition tools for Windows cannot acquire data from a disk's host protected area.
Mini-WinFE enables building a Windows forensic boot CD/DVD or USB drive.
Linux automatically mounts and accesses drives, requiring write-blockers.
Forensic Linux Live CDs are configured to mount connected storage media as read-only.
Validating evidence is optional in computer forensics.
Hashing algorithms like CRC-32, MD5, and SHA are used for validation.
RAID systems are easy to acquire because of their small size.
RAID stands for Redundant Array of Independent Disks.
RAID 0 provides data redundancy through striping.
RAID 1 uses mirroring to duplicate data across two or more disks.
RAID 2 is commonly used today for error correction.
RAID 5 uses block-level striping with distributed parity.
RAID 6 can tolerate only one disk failure.
RAID 10 combines RAID 0 striping with RAID 1 mirroring.
Copying small RAID systems to one large disk is impossible.
Remote network acquisition tools can connect to suspect computers via network connections.
Antivirus tools typically help remote acquisition tools function better.
ProDiscover Incident Response can capture volatile system state information.
PDServer is a remote agent that needs to be loaded on the forensic examiner's computer.
Remote acquisition with EnCase Enterprise supports RAID acquisition.
F-Response is designed to work only with specific digital forensics programs.
PassMark Software ImageUSB is used to create bootable flash drives.
ASRData SMART is a Windows-only forensics analysis tool.
SourceForge provides applications for security, analysis, and investigations.
